title: Strictly's Craig Revel Horwood blames viewers for Catherine exit
text:
Craig thinks viewers need to start voting and stop whinging (Picture: BBC)

Craig Revel-Horwood has blamed the viewers for Catherine Tyldesley’s unexpected departure on Strictly Come Dancing – despite it being the judges’ decision.

The resident Mr Nasty of the judges’ panel appeared on Heart Radio this morning to discuss his new book, but it didn’t take long for the discussion to move about last night’s elimination.

Catherine and pro Johannes Radebe were given the axe this weekend after heading into the dance-off against Mike Bushell and Katya Jones, who were bookies’ favourites to leave.

However, after one last routine, the judges were split into two, with head judge Shirley Ballas making the ultimate decision to send home the Corrie star.

Motsi and Bruno opted to keep Catherine and Johannes, but Craig went to save Mike and Katya.

When asked about whether the worst dancer was eliminated, Craig dodged the question and said that it’s ‘not actually the question’ they’re confronted with.

The judges were split in two over last night’s vote (Picture: BBC)

He told Jamie Theakston and Amanda Holden: ‘For us the judges, we have to judge the dance off only, not what happened previously or what is to become and you can only judge what you see in that one minute thirty and in my opinion Mike had the cleaner dance.

‘It’s quite simple and you know if it was another day or if Catherine was doing a rumba for instance, against his tango, then she would have won it. But you know it’s what happens on the day.’

Craig then said that if you have a problem with the elimination, viewers need to work harder to save their faves.

‘This is the first time that it’s been split, this year actually,’ Craig continued. ‘In previous years it’s been split a lot. Opinion is always split. You know generally when it gets down to this stage because people are very equal in talent and ability.’

‘At the moment, I think on Strictly, it’s becoming obvious that there are people that are really becoming fantastic and they’re leaving some of the rest behind so it’s quite split in that way you know,’ he said.

‘But we always do get the dilemma of two really good ones being in the bottom two.’

‘You have to remember that it’s the audience at home that are putting them in the bottom two as well,’ he added. ‘It’s not just the judges, we have 50% of the vote.

‘I blame the people that aren’t voting you can ask, they’ll all whinge online and be abusive and then you ask them “did you vote?” “Oh no, I didn’t vote” so if you’re that worried about it, vote.’
